reasoning: The critique targets a specific illustrative claim in §2.1 (factory farming possibly outweighing human wellbeing gains) and argues it depends on a particular aggregator/weighting, so it can’t support the broader thesis that moral catastrophe is easy and that most plausible views are fussy. This is only moderately central: the essay’s main case for “no easy eutopia” relies heavily on many other examples of fragility and on the technical argument in §3 about bounded/unbounded value functions and aggregation, so falsifying or undercutting this one example wouldn’t collapse the position. Strength is moderate: it correctly notes that the farmed-animal claim is contentious and may hinge on parameter choices, and it fairly demands robustness across a range of moral weightings if the authors want to treat it as evidence about ‘most plausible’ views. However, it overstates how much the essay relies on this single premise, since §2.1 explicitly frames multiple moral perspectives and §2.3–3.4 provide independent routes to fussiness; so at most it weakens one motivating illustration rather than the core argument. Correctness is fairly high: the dependence on population ethics and animal-vs-human tradeoffs is real, though the critique’s “dominant alternative” framing is somewhat speculative about what is actually driving the authors’ later claims. Clarity is high and it stays tightly on one point with little fluff, hence low dead weight and high single-issue. Overall impact is limited because centrality is modest and the argument doesn’t substantially engage the main technical pillars of the position.
title: Factory farming example may only show some moral views are fussy
